label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, December 4, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, describing a dance he tried to throw for a men that failed because of the lack of women. Sidney continues in his letter to discuss the events of the war and reminisce on the time they spent in Iran.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, describing a dance he tried to throw for a men that failed because of the lack of women. Sidney continues in his letter to discuss the events of the war and reminisce on the time they spent in Iran.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
To Mrs Sidney J. Legendre,
O.S.S. Detachment,
A.PO 887
Postmaster, New York.
From
Lt. S. Legendre, USNR
PO Box 166, Commandant
Navy No. 128
FL PO San Francisco.
December 4, 1943
68
Gertie Darling,
No news from you yet certainly hope I will receive a letter
soon. I arranged a dance for the enlisted men of our activity. It took
place this evening and I am afraid was a fizzle. I just left it and there
were not sufficent girls for the number of men. You know the shotrage of
girls out here is rather acute anyway, but we thought that all the sailors
could round them up. They all had girls when they were ready to leave in
the afternoon. At least the girls were to meet them at the YMCA. However
our boys arrived just a minute after the busses sent out by the army camp
for girls. It seems the army bous strong armed the navy girls into their
dance. I was terribly sorry because they had been looking forward to the
party for a long time and things should have run off very smoothly as they
all worked very hard trying to arrange everything. It was at an a tractive
place , the wailai club. You will remember that we danced there years ago
under the moonlight. Since that time it has burned down but a roofed shelter
has been constructed right on the shore. It is rather attractive with its
sloping roof and hawaiian style of architecture. Of course the faint moon
light from a thin sliver of a new moon, the sound of the surf on the reef
and the smell of ginger in the air all aided the setting. I only stayed a
minute but in that time my mind raced back to the days when you and I use
to be here together, when we danced at Wailai, played tennis and swam in the
blue water. On the way home I stopped on the bluff and looked down on the
sea. The surf white in the half light, the reast of the s ea a deep indigo
blue black. A soft breeze swept across my face and I could almost smell
your perfume and feel you next to me. Could almost touch your hand and hear
you laugh. How long that has been and how long it seems it will be before
we meet again. The war creaks on island to island with a bushful of them
yet to come , I suppose.
Isn't it interesting to see what is going on in old Iran. Just
to think that we were there only a few days a gon, that we know Teheran, and
T. biz, the terrible roads, the dirt and filth of the citires. I bet old
Churchill and Roosevelt will never stay in some of those terrible place
along the border that we did. Do you remember the last night we spent in
Iran at that terrible little inn. How we slept on those boards and in the
morning came down hoping we could hace some kind of breakfast after facing
the primitive washing conditions. All we were given was a kind of tea that
was undrinkable. Then that wonderful train in Irak. That breakfast you had
at the station, with eggs and bacon. Hot coffe and marmalade. What fun that
train trip was up to Baghdad, and how wonderful the Maude hotel seemed. I 
remember walking around and touching everything, the hot water in the tub
was heaven and sitting at the table and eating what was proably very bad
food, was then wonderful. Goodbye darling.
